My [GetFromRelation], [From.GetBestName], has died. Due to my station, I am not expected to mourn for the traditional three years, and may substitute thirty-six months of mourning for thirty-six days. Not mourning at all, however, may still cause significant anger towards me, possibly even jeopardizing my position.

My [GetFromRelation], [From.GetBestName], has died. Due to my station, I am only expected to mourn for one year out of the traditional three. Mourning for less than that will cause significant anger towards me, and not mourning would seriously jeopardize my position.

My [GetFromRelation], [From.GetBestName], has died. Due to my station, I am expected to mourn for the full three years. Less than that would cause significant anger towards me, and mourning too little would seriously jeopardize my position. Not mourning would almost certainly lead to my imprisonment...

My [GetFromRelation], [From.GetBestName], has died. In addition, I have violated the fundamental assumptions of CK2 and am playing as a baron/courtier. I will now contact a developer to debug this event, because this is certainly not supposed to happen.
I will mourn for the full three years.
Three years is too much, a year is enough.
I will substitute months of mourning with days.
I refuse to mourn [From.GetBestName]!

The mourning period for [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] is over, and I am expected to return to my work. I can stay in mourning for a little longer, and it will win me acclaim as a filial [Root.GetSonDaughter], but no one would bat an eye if I chose a return to normalcy.
Finally, I am free of my grief.
I'm not ready yet... another two years, perhaps?

My vassal, [From.GetBestName], has refused to mourn his ancestor for the period demanded of him by our culture. Tradition demands that I take action... perhaps stripping him of his titles would be an appropriate action?
He will be demoted for this.
I literally don't care...

My vassal, [From.GetBestName], has refused to mourn his ancestor for the period demanded of him by our culture. Tradition demands that I take action... perhaps a demotion and a stay in the dungeon will remind him of his duties of filial piety?
It certainly would!
I literally don't care...

I am sitting around in my family mansion one day when one of my servants approaches me timidly. "My [Root.GetLordLady]," he stammers out. "People on the street are doubting your filial piety. Perhaps you should emulate the ancients and live in a shack by your ancestors' graves to show your devotion?"
Sure, I will make the preparations.
Live in a what? Never!

I see my servants whispering to each other whenever I order my meal to be served up. Although I have reduced the opulence of my meals, it seems that they think the reductions I have made are insufficient and only for show. Perhaps I should do something to rectify that...
I will eat even less from now on.
Why do I even bother with the diet?

As expected of a mourning child, I wear white clothes made of hemp. However, I find it uncomfortable compared to my normal silks and finery. Perhaps a little lapse from mourning traditions would be welcome here?
No one will care about a small slip.
My clothes show my filial piety!
Due to my grief I have neglected caring for my appearance. My hair is dishevelled and those around me have begun to gossip that I might be too absorbed in my grief to care for myself properly.
I will fix my hair.
It would be improper.

It is customary to mourn the dead with offerings of incense and paper money, as well as cleaning up their grave site. I could spend some money on offerings for my recently deceased ancestor, and it would be the pious thing to do, but then again, money is money...
I will buy incense to burn before their now-cleaned graves.
That sounds like a waste of money and time.

Some say that the dead never truly leave us, and that the living can commune with them if the correct rites and rituals are used. While this is dismissed by orthodox scholars as nothing but fanciful superstition, after the loss of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] I am much more tempted to believe in such things...
It is worth investigating.
I am no fool.

After weeks of dedicated study, I have finally mastered the ritual. At my command, the spirit of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] appears before me. It is just like [ancestor_to_mourn.GetSheHe] is alive again, and we converse for hours until my power is exhausted and [ancestor_to_mourn.GetSheHe] has to depart once more. It is like a weight has been lifted from my mind.
Until we meet again.

After weeks of dedicated study, I am forced to conclude that my research has reached a dead end. None of the rituals I attempt come close to bringing me to a reunion with [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName], and perhaps no such ritual exists at all. Will I truly never see [ancestor_to_mourn.GetHerHim] again?
I have learnt much about the occult, at least.

After the death of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName], I find myself drifting around, bereft of all motivation. Grief is at least something that I can understand, but this crushing emptiness is beyond grief, sapping all of my drive and desire.
Is there truly nothing left for me?

While the days of mourning are a time of grief, for me, they have also proven to be a welcome respite from the struggles of everyday life. The requirement of abstinence from almost all other actions has given me time to relax and let out some of my pent-up stress.
A time for relaxation...

While the days of mourning have allowed me to relax and relief myself of some stress, it has also caused me to regard my work with less importance. After all, it feels so much better not diligently hammering away at every detail on those official papers...
Diligence is overrated anyways.
No! I must not allow myself to become lazy!

While I have chosen to follow a different faith from [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName], [ancestor_to_mourn.GetHerHis] blood still flows through my veins. Perhaps I should try to understand [ancestor_to_mourn.GetHerHis] faith, and thus [ancestor_to_mourn.GetHerHim], a little better?
It is part of my heritage, after all.
I must not lose sight of my own faith.

I am a high-ranking official, and I should certainly have the resources to dedicate a large offering of food and wealth to the spirit of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName]. However, while pious, such large offerings are seen as arrogant and unbecoming of a mourning child.
Go ahead with the offering.
No, it would just be a show of pride.

[also_mourning_relative.GetBestName], is also in mourning. Having just lost a close  relative, I can understand [also_mourning_relative.GetHerHis] pain. Perhaps I should approach [also_mourning_relative.GetHerHim] and offer my sympathies? It could be an opportunity to improve our relationship by sharing our grief.
I will write [also_mourning_relative.GetHerHim] a letter.
I won't want to bother [also_mourning_relative.GetHerHim].

My [GetFromRelation], [From.GetBestName], has just written me a letter consoling me on my recent loss. This could certainly be an opportunity to strengthen our relationship, but at the same time [From.GetSheHe] is remarkably forward and [From.GetHerHis] letter could be represented as an attempt to rub salt into my wounds.
I will reciprocate [From.GetHerHis] kindness.
I will rebuff [From.GetHerHis] attempts at commiseration.
I have received a positive response from [From.GetBestName]. It seems that my sympathies were received and appreciated.
As a fellow mourner, [From.GetSheHe] knows my pain.

I have received a strongly worded response from [From.GetBestName], informing me that [From.GetSheHe] has no wish to speak with me. [From.GetSheHeCap] tells me in no uncertain terms to mind my own business and leave [From.GetHerHim] to [From.GetHerHis] grief.
I just wanted to help...

In recent days, I have found myself more and more paralysed by the thought of death. The death of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] has reminded me that no one is immortal, and it seems that fear of my own death has finally caught up with me.
Anyone could be plotting to kill me!
I must accept this looming inevitability.
I will face my fears head-on.

In recent days, I have found myself thinking about death. The death of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] has reminded me that no one has unlimited time, and I must strive to accomplish something soon before my death if I wish to be remembered.
I will redouble my efforts and strive for excellence.
My legacy will speak for itself.
Perhaps it is time to think about curbing my ambition.

In recent days, I have found myself becoming more friendly towards others. The death of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] has reminded me that we are all merely residing temporarily in this world, and perhaps I should be kinder to my fellow lodgers.
I could help others with my wealth.
I should set aside more time for those around me.
Kindness is a weakness within myself that I must root out.

In recent days, I have found myself humbled by the enormity of death. The death of [ancestor_to_mourn.GetBestName] has reminded me that status in this world means nothing before mortality, and in the end our fates are subject to greater powers than our own.
I shall devote myself to the higher powers.
